items.title: Unicode Decode Error for invalid UTF-8
items.body:
For invalid Unicode Decode Error, it gets me an error at this point:

https://github.com/hardikvasa/google-images-download/blob/0d2bf8f17b5a8806d90df7258e7a172aa0cb7963/google_images_download/google_images_download.py#L922

here is my fix:
```python
 try:
    print(iteration.encode('raw_unicode_escape').decode('utf-8'))
except:
    print(iteration.encode('raw_unicode_escape').decode('latin-1'))
```

items.title: Downloading related images produces incorrect directory syntax
items.body:
When downloading with the --related-images parameter, the downloader tries to create a directory with an invalid name and crashes.

For example (Windows 10, Python 3.6):
`python google_images_download.py -k "disc brake" -l 10 -ri `

...produces:
`Item no.: 1 --> Item name = disc brake`
`Evaluating...`
`Starting Download...`
`Completed Image ====> 1. 1200px-disk_brake_dsc03682.jpg`
`Completed Image ====> 2. 1175-front.jpg`
`...`
`Completed Image ====> 10. car-disc-brake-cluster.jpg`

`Getting list of related keywords...this may take a few moments`

`Now Downloading - disc brake - disc+brake,g_1:motorcycle:SsiXX7r2me8%3D&usg=AI4_-kQTz_e6pgr8yN7IAZTX6buWsweNYg&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjC-_Hw0f_gAhWRonEKHYzLB1kQ4lYIKCgB`

`OSError: [WinError 123] The filename, directory name, or volume label syntax is incorrect: 'downloads\\disc brake - disc+brake,g_1:motorcycle:SsiXX7r2me8%3D&usg=AI4_-kQTz_e6pgr8yN7IAZTX6buWsweNYg&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjC-_Hw0f_gAhWRonEKHYzLB1kQ4lYIKCgB'`

The `create_directories()` function is trying to create a directory that contains invalid characters, or sometimes the directory path is too long.

I think the problem arises because at the end of the `download()` function, it calls `get_all_tabs()` and extracts `item_name` which becomes appended to the path. I can probably fix this and submit a pull request, although am a bit unsure what the desired behaviour should be, so any suggestions welcome.

items.title: x-raw-image
items.body:
Hello,
I am using googleimagesdownload to get the URLs of images found on google.
I am using the CLI from within python and saving the printed URLs:

```
import subprocess
result = {'label': 'The Elements of Moral Philosophy', 'author': 'James Rachels'}
item_type = 'book'
out = subprocess.check_output(["googleimagesdownload", "--keywords", "\"%s %s %s\"" % (result['label'].replace(',',''), item_type, result['author']), "--print_urls", "-l", "1"])
url = out.decode('utf-8').split('\n')[4].replace('Image URL: ','') 
```

items.title: related_images download failed, and I have resolved this bug.
items.body:
I used to download a ton of images related to my keyword by adding '--related_images' or '-ri' in my query. and it worked very well. But recently, it don't work, it just downloads images from my keywords, no any related images.

I have been tossing for a long time. Finally, I resolved this bug! It seems that google has updated its html format. And you just need to find 'get_next_tab(self,s)' function and modify 3 lines code. Or you can copy and replace the function below 

```
def get_next_tab(self,s):
    start_line = s.find('class="dtviD"')#class="ZO5Spb"
    if start_line == -1:  # If no links are found then give an error!
        end_quote = 0
        link = "no_tabs"
        return link,'',end_quote
    else:
        start_line = s.find('class="dtviD"')#class="ZO5Spb"
        start_content = s.find('href="', start_line + 1)
        end_content = s.find('">', start_content + 1)
        url_item = "https://www.google.com" + str(s[start_content+6:end_content])
        url_item = url_item.replace('&', '&')
        start_line_2 = s.find('class="dtviD"')#class="ZO5Spb"
        start_content_2 = s.find(':', start_line_2 + 1)
        end_content_2 = s.find('"', start_content_2 + 1)
        url_item_name = str(s[start_content_2 + 1:end_content_2])
        return url_item,url_item_name,end_content
```

items.title: Multiple file format in a single request
items.body: It's probably more of a feature request. If you search for certain terms and only want results in certain file formats (e.g. jpg, png, svg), only one file format can be specified. Google can only use one format too, but it may be possible to use different file extensions. E.g. by an iterating search over the formats.

items.title: Set filename of download
items.body:
**Use Case:** I wanted to download the first result for 800 lines.  Doing so with a four digit prefix created file names such as `0011 1. logo-new.png` where the first 4 digit number is my index, the ` 1. ` is google-images-download's number and then the original filename.

While prefix is available, I wasn't able to find a way to completely set the filename. 

In my scenario I'm iterating through a CSV file and downloading the first result only.  I would like to name that as `0000.jpg` to correspond with the CSV line item. 

Not a big deal to go through and do a bulk re-name, but would be handy to skip this step.  I guess this feature would only be available if limit is set to 1 or give the option for a numbering convention like 0001-001.jpg

To clean up the file names after my download I ran:

```
import glob, os

path =  os.getcwd()
filenames = os.listdir(path)

for filename in filenames:
    split = filename.split('.')

    new = split[0][:-1] + "." + split[-1]
    print new
    os.rename(filename, new)
```

as a separate Python script.

items.title: Bug - The time_range filter is ignored and the same images are returned
items.body:
Hi,
In the python implementation - 
file **google_images_download.py, line 353.**
In the function **build_url_parameters**, for the switch on **time_range**:

`if arguments['time_range']:`

The value of time_range has a redundant ampersand (&) before "cdr" - **&cdr**

`time_range = '&cdr:1,cd_min:' + d['time_min'] + ',cd_max:' + d['time_min']`

It should be **cdr**

`time_range = 'cdr:1,cd_min:' + d['time_min'] + ',cd_max:' + d['time_min']`

Without fixing it, google will ignore the filtering by time_range.

**Code example for reproducing the error:**
Both cases return **the same images** although we specify **different time_min and time_max** (it simply ignores the time_range filter):

**Case 1 - 'time_range': str({"time_min":"04/05/2017","time_max":"04/06/2017"}),**
```
response = google_images_download.googleimagesdownload()
arguments = {"keywords": "dog",
             "limit": 3,
             "print_urls": True,
             'time_range': str({"time_min":"04/05/2017","time_max":"04/06/2017"}),
             "output_directory" : '/home/dan/google_images_download/downloads/'}
response.download(arguments)  # passing the arguments to the function
```

**Case 2 - 'time_range': str({"time_min":"04/08/2017","time_max":"04/09/2017"}),**
```
response = google_images_download.googleimagesdownload()
arguments = {"keywords": "dog",
             "limit": 3,
             "print_urls": True,
             'time_range': str({"time_min":"04/08/2017","time_max":"04/09/2017"}),
             "output_directory" : '/home/dan/google_images_download/downloads/'}
response.download(arguments)  # passing the arguments to the function
```




Thanks,
Dan.

items.title: Unicode keyword cause problem when printing to console on Windows
items.body: Hi Hardik and guys, Thanks for this great tool. I'd like to report an issue, when using non-English search word, it causes the program to throw an error and quit. I'm not sure if this is specific to some platform or locale. Mine is Windows 10 64-bit English version. I tried to use some Thai words and the error occurs on the print(iteration) line. Obviously this is just a status message which the program would work just fine if the line is commented out. I learned that we're only supposed to use characters in the string.printable when outputting to console. So my solution is to replace the line with print(iteration.encode(encoding='utf-8', errors='replace')), which will replace non-printable characters with their Unicode escape sequence e.g. "\xe0\xb8\xad\" which works fine for me. But I'm not sure which is the best way to fix or which is your preferred way. So let me know if I can help. Thanks.
